statement.text: Syme amputation is an ankle disarticulation that preserves the specialized weight-bearing heel pad, creating a durable end-bearing stump that allows limited ambulation without prosthesis and excellent prosthetic function.

explanation.intuition: The heel pad is uniquely designed to bear the body's weight with its specialized fat and fibrous tissue. By preserving this natural cushion and attaching it to the end of the tibia, patients can stand briefly without a prosthesis - like having a built-in pad.
explanation.key_insight: The key to successful Syme is meticulous preservation of the heel pad and its blood supply (posterior tibial artery). The heel pad must be centered under the tibia for proper end-bearing function.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: ankle joint disarticulated, malleoli shaved flush, heel flap developed preserving posterior tibial artery, heel pad sutured to anterior skin. Critical elements: (1) Viable heel pad (posterior tibial perfusion), (2) Smooth bone surface, (3) Centered heel pad positioning. Contraindications: non-functional heel pad, severe posterior tibial disease. Prosthetics: specialized Syme prosthesis with low-profile foot.

procedural_details.key_feature: Preserves specialized heel pad for end-bearing
critical_requirements: Viable heel pad with posterior tibial supply
procedural_details.prosthetics: Specialized Syme prosthesis with low-profile design

primary_sources.title: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery

clinical_pearls: Success depends on viable posterior tibial blood supply to heel pad
Heel pad must be centered under tibia for end-bearing function
Allows limited household ambulation without prosthesis
